intro: Rhynchospora fibrillosa, commonly known as the hairy spike-rush, is a perennial grass-like plant native to wetland habitats in North America. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges and other similar plants. The plant is characterized by its tall, cylindrical inflorescence composed of small, spike-like clusters of flowers. Its leaves are typically narrow and covered with fine, hairy structures, giving it its common name. Rhynchospora fibrillosa plays an important ecological role in stabilizing wetland soils and providing habitat for various invertebrates.
